name: Marimokkori
description: The name 'Marimokkori' is a portmanteau: marimo is the word for the green algae clusters that grow in some of Hokkaidō's lakes, while mokkori, literally 'bulge', is a Japanese slang term for an erection.

name: Melon-kuma
description: A bear with a yubari melon on its head.

name: Kyun-chan
description: Kyun-chan is a northern pika, a small furry rabbit-like animal (ezo naki usagi) found only in Hokkaido. He's really shy and that's why wears a Hokkaido deer hat (ezo shika) to hide his shyness.

name: IburiOne Jr.
description: A pink dog

name: Kiko-chan
description: A red bull

name: Kazumo-chan
description: A piece of herring roe

name: Ikaaru Seijin
description: The Man from Planet Ikaaru, an alien squid

name: Jingis Khan No Jin-Kun
japanese: ジンギスカンのジンくん
description: Jingis Khan represents a local delicacy by the same name, which is a cook-it-yourself dish including mutton

name: Nipo-kun
description: A mascot modeled on a traditional toy made by the local Ainu tribes.

name: Sarupu
description: A monkey with a scallop crown and a cow-print onesie. He weighs the same as 90 scallops.

name: Laveton
description: A pig dressed in lavendar.  Kamifurano is famous for both lavendar and pork.

name: Soraisu
description: A sky blue squirrel with cloud hair.

name: Milkuman
description: A bear with an ice cream cone on his head.

name: Frep the Fox
japanese: フレップ・ザ・フォックス
mascot: The Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters Baseball Team
description: An Ezo red fox, who debuted in March 2016. He is gray with red markings, and he is considered an 'apprentice.'

name: Polly Polaris
mascot: The Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters Baseball Team
description: A brown squirrel who appeared late 2012, at the same time when the Fighters announced their 10th season. She's the first female mascot that was introduced to the team.

name: Cubby the Bear
mascot: The Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters Baseball Team
description: a brown bear and younger brother of B·B. He appeared in 2006 as the mascot of the Fighters' minor league team, based in Kamagaya, Chiba. Cubby and B·B performed for each team, but also sometimes perform together when the Fighters' professional team plays in Tokyo.

name: B.B. (Brisky the Bear)
mascot: The Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters Baseball Team
description: A black bear with a ruffle of black or orange hair on his head. He first appeared in 2004, as the successor to Fighty. When B·B was first introduced, his appearance was criticized by some of the Fighters' supporters for being too Americanized. On the Fighters official website, B·B has his own picture gallery and column.

name: Fighty
mascot: The Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters Baseball Team
description: A bright pink pterodactyl whose head resembled a giant leg of ham and who sometimes rode a bicycle around the field. Fighty was retired, despite the (unsuccessful) 'Save Fighty' campaign, when the Fighters moved to Hokkaido.

name: TV Tosan
description: The Sapporo TV Tower, with a mustache

name: Moko
mascot: The Japanese Self Defense Force - Hokkaido
description: A sheep with a cute camouflage bowtie.

name: Kibicchi
description: A walking ear of corn that represents Odori Park, a park full of carts of fresh corn

name: Kiyotchi
description: His abstract art hat is the local logo, a K for Kiyota.

name: Kappon
description: His full name is “Jozankei Kappa Kokichibei”. One day, he was playing with his friends on the banks of the Toyohira River with a bucket that had floated downstream, and shouting out “kappon!” he squeezed himself into the bucket and couldn’t get back out. From that day, everyone called him ‘Kappon’! Kappon loves hot springs and always brings his own towel and bucket with him, because he thinks it’s convenient to bring them to the hot springs himself.

name: Ezomon
description: A Hokkaido flying squirrel

name: Dole-kun
description: Modeled on the Blakiston's Fish Owl -- the largest owl in Japan and a very well-known denizen of Hokkaido.

name: Matagi no Momiji-chan
japanese: またぎのもみじちゃん
description: A gun toting pink yezo sika deer, often seen with Jingis Khan No Jin-Kun

name: Ikube
description: He is a blue traveling fairy who fell in love with Aomori prefecture after wandering around Japan. Because of this love, he decided to live in Aomori (which means 'blue forest')

name: Wanko
description: Inspired by a 'wanko soba' noodle, a famous local food in Iwate prefecture. Wanko consists of 5 brothers, each of them has a different motif and character.

name: Musubimaru
description: A rice ball samurai. Rice is famous produce in Miyagi and its armor design comes after the local hero'Masamune Date'

name: Sugitchi
description: An Akita cedar tree, retired in 2017 after 10 years of service

name: Kizakura Sui
japanese: 黄桜すいプロジェクト
description: A 16-year-old water goddess that is 158 centimeters tall and likes the Akita Komachi variety of rice, soft serve ice cream, and cats

name: Kitekeru-kun
description: This mascot is overshadowed by Kumamons popularity.

name: Kibitan
description: Based on the local 'Kibitaki' bird (the narcissus flycatcher). He was originally created for a nineties athletics event and now represents hopeful renewal for Fukushima.

name: Hustle Komon
description: A character inspired by the long-running TV period drama, Mito Komon.

name: Tochimarukun
description: A little hard worker

name: Gunma-chan
description: A cute pony from Gunma prefecture

name: Kobaton
description: The mascot of Saitama prefecture, Kobaton is a Eurasian collared dove, which is also the prefectural bird. Kobaton was made originally as the mascot of the fifty-ninth annual national athletic meeting held in the prefecture in 2004, and was inaugurated as mascot of the prefecture in 2005 with an inauguration ceremony and a letter of appointment from the governor. A wheelchair-using version of Kobaton also exists.

name: Chiba-kun
description: A mysterious red animal from Chiba Prefecture whose shape comes from the geography of the prefecture

name: Reruhi-San
description: TThe 270cm-tall skiing mascot based on Theodor Von-Lerch, an Austro-Hungarian major who brought the skiing to Japan

name: Hyakumansan
description: 'Mr. One Million', generally unpopular because he is considered to be ugly

name: Sautan
description: A dinosaur, meant to represent the many dinosaur fossils found in Fukui.  Part of the Juratic mascot group.

name: Hishimaru Takeda
description: A member of the Takeda clan

name: Arukuma
description: A walking bear with an Nagano apple hat

name: Minamo
description: A smiling sprite

name: Fujippi
description: If Mt Fuji was a person

name: Kappasalamander
description: A hybrid of a kappa and an axolotl.

name: Mametan
description: A walking bean pod

name: Haropon
description: A racoon dog witch

name: Omozo
description: A square elephant

name: Ringori-kun
description: A mix of a baby gorilla and an apple

name: Bun-chan
description: A monkey with a newspaper hat

name: Bun-chan
mascot: Bunkaru, a PR website run by Japan's Agency for Cultural Affairs
description: A rosy cheeked mascot

name: Haniwa Kacho / Haniwa Bucho
description: An office manager with the head of an ancient clay figure

name: Swatch
description: A patchwork elephant that is a reincarnation of Suwako, an elephant that once lived in the zoo

name: Kuroneko Shironeko
description: A black cat and white cat serve as mascots for Yamato Transport Company.  These cats are represented in various illustrations including the famous Kuroneko logo of a mom cat carrying a baby cat.

name: Paiko-chan
description: A terrifyingly sexual pink bird

name: Pay-kun
description: A credit card weilding squirrel, he serves as the mascot for Payment Navi, a Japanese credit card information site

name: Hanako
description: A white elephant nurse

name: Zombear
description: He’s a big stuffed teddy bear who has been wandering the streets of Hokkaido for 70 years looking for the boy that owns him. He’s got a very bad sense of direction, but is lucky nonetheless.

name: Ponta
description: A racoon dog, the official mascot for the Ponta Points program through Lawson

name: Nanaco
description: A giraffe, the official mascot for the Nanaco rewards program and payment service through 7-Eleven

name: Asaga-Ossan
description: An old man who loves booze and has a morning glory flower for a head.

name: Dennyas
description: Three cats that represent Dennys

name: Shugar
description: A cross between a polar bear and a sugar cube.

name: Rippy
description: A rabbit often mistaken for a hamster

name: Psychedelhi-san
description: A mildly racist Indian psychidelic mushroom.  Chosen in a contest that included over 890 designs, it is truly unknown to us why this one was picked.

name: Tomato Ninjen
description: A weird tomato, also the mascot of Kouenji.  Usually appears with Psychedelhi-san

name: Kawacchi
description: A philosophical kappa

name: Sunna-chan
description: A smiling coral fairy

name: Takausagi
description: A grumpy hybrid of a rabbit and a falcon

name: Coppel-kun
description: A flamboyant Danish seagull

name: Hummer-kun
description: A seagull with shades

name: Inunakin
description: A hero dog

name: Manmoshi
mascot: East Nippon Expressway Safe Driving in the Snow
description: A wooly mammoth who teaches the people of Japan how to safely drive in snow.

name: Manbe-kun
description: A boy with crab claws, scallop ears, and an iris for hair.

name: Ono-kun
description: A sockey monkey mascot modeled after the event when citizens sewed toys out of socks to help raise funds to rebuild the city after an earthquake.
